Package au.edu.anu.rscs.aot.collections.tables

Class IndexString

  • java.lang.Object
    • au.edu.anu.rscs.aot.collections.tables.IndexString
  • public class IndexString
extends java.lang.Object

    Static methods to describe multidimensional indexes using a string with a R -like syntax.

    For example, for a 3D table "TABLE" of dimensions 3,5,2:

    • TABLE[||] or TABLE = the whole table (all indices)
    • TABLE[2|4|1] = cell (2,4,1) of the table
    • TABLE[|4|1] = cells (0,4,1) (1,4,1) and (2,4,1), ie all items in dimension 1
    • TABLE[3||] = all items in dimensions 2 and 3, cell 3 only in dimension 1
    • 1:3 = specifies a range of indices in one dimension, in this case indices 1, 2 and 3
    • 1,3,7 = specifies the three indexes in one dimension, in this case indices 1, 3 and 7
    • -2 = all indices in the dimension except index 2
    • -1:3 = all indicies in the dimension except 1,2 and 3
    Author:
    Jacques Gignoux - 23 oct. 2019

    • Method Detail

      • stringIndexRanges

        public static au.edu.anu.rscs.aot.util.IntegerRange[] stringIndexRanges​(java.lang.String indexString,
                                                                        int... dim)
        Given a string index, returns the range of indices in each dimension.
        Parameters:
        indexString - a String describing an index - e.g. "[0;2:3|0;2|-1]"
        dim - the dimensions of the table this string applies to - e.g. 4,4,2
        Returns:
        the min and max index values in every dimension - e.g. [ 0..3 0..2 0..0 ]

      • stringToIndex

        public static int[][] stringToIndex​(java.lang.String indexString,
                                    Table table)
        This method converts a string describing an index range to a list of indices usable by the Table class and its descendants.
        Parameters:
        indexString - the String containing the index description - e.g. "[1:3,2:3,]"
        table - the Table this string applies to - e.g. myTable = new BooleanTable(new Dimensioner(4),new Dimensioner(5),new Dimensioner(3))
        Returns:
        an array of array of indices of the same dimension as the table - e.g. [[1,2,0] [1,2,1] [1,2,2] [1,3,0] [1,3,1] [1,3,2] [2,2,0] [2,2,1] [2,2,2] [2,3,0] [2,3,1] [2,3,2] [3,2,0] [3,2,1] [3,2,2] [3,3,0] [3,3,1] [3,3,2]]

      • stringToIndex

        public static int[][] stringToIndex​(java.lang.String indexString,
                                    int... dim)
        This method converts a string describing an index range to a list of indices usable by the Table class and its descendants.
        Parameters:
        indexString - the String containing the index description - e.g. "[1:3,2:3,]"
        dim - the dimensions of the table this string applies to - e.g. 4,5,3
        Returns:
        an array of arrays of indices of the same dimension as the table - e.g. [[1,2,0] [1,2,1] [1,2,2] [1,3,0] [1,3,1] [1,3,2] [2,2,0] [2,2,1] [2,2,2] [2,3,0] [2,3,1] [2,3,2] [3,2,0] [3,2,1] [3,2,2] [3,3,0] [3,3,1] [3,3,2]]

      • indexToString

        public static java.lang.String indexToString​(int[][] index,
                                             int... dim)

        This method converts an array of indices into a String.

        CAUTION: this is NOT performing the reverse operation to stringToIndex(...) as the factoring out of a table of indices is not unique and tricky to work out. This uses a ndim arrays of indices selected in each of the dimensions independently and works out the global String matching these.

        Assumes indices are provided in proper order.

        Parameters:
        index - a ndim-list of indices to search for in every dimension - e.g. {{0,1,2,4},{2,4,5,6,8,9,11},null}
        dim - ndim dimension sizes - e.g. 5,12,8
        Returns:
        the matching String - e.g. "[0:2;4|2;4:6;8:9;11|]"

      • indexToString

        public static java.lang.String indexToString​(int[][] index,
                                             Table table)

        This method converts an array of indices into a String.

        CAUTION: this is NOT performing the reverse operation to stringToIndex(...) as the factoring out of a table of indices is not unique and tricky to work out. This uses a ndim arrays of indices selected in each of the dimensions independently and works out the global String matching these.

        Assumes indices are provided in proper order.

        Parameters:
        index - a ndim-list of indices to search for in every dimension - e.g. {{0,1,2,4},{2,4,5,6,8,9,11},null}
        table - the Table this string applies to - e.g. myTable = new ShortTable(new Dimensioner(5),new Dimensioner(12),new Dimensioner(8))
        Returns:
        the matching String - e.g. "[0:2;4|2;4:6;8:9;11|]"
